items.content_html:
Description

This PR fixes the auto-generated ID for "changeInfo" on the tabs.onUpdated page. The previous ID was causing the link to point to its own <dt> element instead of the intended section.

Motivation

  • Seamless and intuitive user experience for MDN readers.

Additional details

  • Issue #14196.

Related issues and pull requests

  • Fixes #14196
items.title: Fix auto-generated ID for "changeInfo" on the tabs.onUpdated page

items.content_html: The link text and further description did not meaningfully match the linked article.
items.title: Correct solving js problems link text, description

items.content_html:
Description

Expectation:
Without "use strict"; I expected y to be available in the outer scope and for no ReferenceError to occur.

Observation:
Without "use strict"; y is not available in the outer scope.

Testing scenarios: Safari 16.3, Firefox 110.0.1, Chromium 110.0.5481.100 Test document:

<html>
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <title></title>
</head>
<body>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        (function foo() {
            var x = 1;
            function bar() {
                var y = 2;
                console.log(x); // 1 (function `bar` closes over `x`)
                console.log(y); // 2 (`y` is in scope)
            }
            bar();
            console.log(x); // 1 (`x` is in scope)
            console.log(y); // ReferenceError, `y` is scoped only to `bar` without 'use strict';
        })();
    </script>
</body>
</html>

Motivation

The outcome is the same regardless if you are in strict mode or not.

Additional details

While reading and learning, this section really confused me so I want to help clarify it for others.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Remove Redundant "use strict";

items.content_html:
Description

This PR offers a minor edit pass to the web app manifest page. It was a bit outdated and I thought could be made more current and clearer.

This PR also contains ref docs for file_handlers which is a manifest member that allows installed PWAs to become handlers for files at the operating system level.

Motivation

This is part of the parent PWA docs revamp project: mdn/mdn#280

In this project, we're rewriting the PWA docs entirely. And part of it is to make sure the manifest ref docs are correct too.

Additional details

For more information about file_handlers:

  • Docs
    • https://developer.chrome.com/articles/file-handling/
    • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/progressive-web-apps-chromium/how-to/handle-files
  • Feature tracking
    • https://chromestatus.com/feature/5721776357113856

Related issues and pull requests

We need this BCD PR to be merged too: mdn/browser-compat-data#19096
items.title: Update web app manifest page and add missing `file_handlers` member

items.content_html:
Description

Added notes concerning the fact that, depending on the underlying OS, "prefers-reduced-motion" does not mean reduced motion, but instead removed/disabled all animations, not specific to motion.

Motivation

The existing article does not consider that fact that some systems and users don't indicate preference for reduced motion, but actually removed animations.
items.title: Clarify OS dependent user preference meaning

items.content_html:
Description

Add the Safari-specific "autocapitalize" attribute to the existing list of non-standard attributes.

Motivation

It is useful for web developers to easily discover that an attribute they are trying to use is non-standard.

Additional details

This Safari-specific attribute is documented here:

https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariHTMLRef/Articles/Attributes.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40008058-autocapitalize

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Add Safari's "autocapitalize" to list of non-standard attributes

See section 5.1

items.content_html:
Associated BCD PR: mdn/browser-compat-data#19082

This is part of openwebdocs/project#152

I created all AudioProcessingEvent.* pages, including AudioProcessingEvent() even if not supported by Firefox (and strictly speaking outside the scope of the Q1 projects). As the interface is deprecated and, usually, the ctor is not called directly by the user code, I skipped writing an example for it. (It would have been cumbersome to test for next to no use).
items.title: Create AudioProcessingEvent.* docs

items.content_html:
Fixes #24957.

This PR:

  • fixes the type of event passed into the handler (ErrorEvent not UIEvent)
  • tries to be more explicit about the fact that the weirdness about cancelling the event only applies to the event handler property onerror.
items.title: Clarify Window.onerror behavior

items.content_html:
Motivation

This discussion describes the existing inconsistencies across the See also sections and the proposed set of guidelines to follow from here on.

Details of changes

  • In the Writing style guide:
  1. With the non-implementation of exposing H3 headings in the page TOC on the right, added a mini TOC in each of the three H2 sections "General writing guidelines", "Writing style", and "Page components".
  2. Upgraded "Shortened URLs (shortlinks)" from H4 to H3 and also edited the section a bit.
  3. Added the "See also section" section per the proposal in the discussion.
  4. Updated the "See also" section of the Writing style guide to comply with the new guidelines.
  • In the template files:
    Updated the "See also" section to refer to the guidelines in the writing style guide.

TO DO

  • Organize sub-sections in the writing style guide in alphabetical order.
  • Update "See also" sections in the pages used as examples in the discussion.
items.title: docs(meta): Add See also section guidelines to writing style guide

items.content_html:
Description

This PR is part of a multi-PR series that aims to document the WebGPU API. The interfaces documented in this PR are:

  • GPUCompilationInfo (done)
  • GPUCompilationMessage (done)
  • GPUDeviceLostInfo
  • GPUError
  • GPUInternalError
  • GPUOutOfMemoryError
  • GPUPipelineError
  • GPUQuerySet
  • GPUUncapturedErrorEvent
  • GPUValidationError

Note that the main PR for this series is #24202 — that one must be merged first, before this one! after that one is merged, main should be merged into this PR, and the documentation integrity must be checked (e.g. do all the links work) before merging.

You can see full details of the additions expected in the WebGPU docs in my research document.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: WebGPU PR #4 — Interfaces for handling errors and queries
